perturbation.original_text: Either Party may terminate this agreement for non-cause with a sixty (60) written notice.
perturbation.changed_text: Either Party may terminate this agreement for non-cause with a thirty (30) written notice.
perturbation.explanation: This change introduces a conflict with typical contract law standards, as 60 days is a more standard and reasonable notice period. Shortening it to 30 days may be deemed insufficient, particularly if the reseller has made significant investments based on the agreement. While not directly violating a statute, it weakens the enforceability based on reasonableness and fairness, potentially leading to legal challenges under general contract principles. It could be argued that 30 days is not enough time to wind down operations or find a replacement, especially if the reseller has a substantial customer base.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General Contract Principles - Reasonableness and Fairness

perturbation.original_text: Referral Fees will be paid within thirty (30) days of the collection of receivables from the Registered Referral.
perturbation.changed_text: Referral Fees will be paid within sixty (60) days of the collection of receivables from the Registered Referral.
perturbation.explanation: This change extends the payment period for referral fees. While not a direct violation of a specific law, extending payment terms can create issues under state prompt payment laws, particularly if those laws mandate shorter payment periods for subcontractors or similar relationships. It might also violate general business practices that promotes payment within a reasonable time and it may be deemed unconscionable.
perturbation.contradicted_law: State Prompt Payment Laws, General Contract Principles

perturbation.original_text:
This Agreement may be terminated by Reseller for cause immediately upon the occurrence of any of the following events: (i) if the use or sale of Company Products are enjoined due to any claim of infringement of any U.S. patent or copyright or of any misappropriation of trade secrets; (ii) if Company ceases to do business, or otherwise terminates its business operations; or (iii) if Company breaches any provision of this Agreement and fails to fully cure such breach within fifteen (15) business days of written notice from Reseller describing the breach.

This Agreement may be terminated by Company for cause immediately upon the occurrence of any of the following events: (i) if Reseller ceases to do business, or otherwise terminates its business operations; or (ii) if Reseller breaches any provision of this Agreement and fails to fully cure such breach within fifteen (15) business days of written notice from Company describing the breach.
perturbation.changed_text:
This Agreement may be terminated by Reseller for cause immediately upon the occurrence of any of the following events: (i) if the use or sale of Company Products are enjoined due to any claim of infringement of any U.S. patent or copyright or of any misappropriation of trade secrets; (ii) if Company ceases to do business, or otherwise terminates its business operations; or (iii) if Company breaches any provision of this Agreement and fails to fully cure such breach within five (5) business days of written notice from Reseller describing the breach.

This Agreement may be terminated by Company for cause immediately upon the occurrence of any of the following events: (i) if Reseller ceases to do business, or otherwise terminates its business operations; or (ii) if Reseller breaches any provision of this Agreement and fails to fully cure such breach within five (5) business days of written notice from Company describing the breach.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the cure period from 15 to 5 business days is potentially problematic. While parties can generally agree on cure periods, extremely short periods can be deemed unreasonable and unenforceable. This is especially true if the breach involves complex issues requiring more time to resolve. A five-day cure period might be challenged as insufficient, violating principles of good faith and fair dealing, and potentially conflicting with state laws requiring reasonable opportunity to cure breaches, leading to unenforceability of the termination clause. Certain complex breaches will undoubtedly require more than 5 days to cure, therefore this clause is unreasonable.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General Contract Law - Reasonableness of Cure Period, Good Faith and Fair Dealing
